intro: Calandrinia volubilis var. parvula, commonly known as the dwarf sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and showy pink to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its small, trailing growth habit makes it suitable for rock gardens and xeriscaping. The flowers bloom in summer and attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
